Dear Ms. Koziara:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
5/14/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s
performance annually thereafter.
2

Two of seven new employee files reviewed requiring evaluations lacked
evaluations being completed withing the probationary period.
Repeat Violation Established
2022 Renewal, CAP approved 4/29/2022.
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 6/9/2023.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an updated treatment plan for each
resident at least once every 90-calendar days
following the initial treatment plan.
One of three current youth files reviewed had an updated treatment plan
completed over 90 days.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 6/9/2023.
IV. T ECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• CCI Rule 400.4113 (1) (j): The facility should implement a tracking system for
when probationary employee evaluations are due and send out reminders a
month prior to supervisors who are completing the evaluations.
• RFCAN 2.10 Services to be provided u) Behavioral Health Services 20 Psychiatric
Services: Within 15 calendar days of the youth’s admission to the facility, if
necessary, from the youth’s treatment plan, the psychiatrist must assess the youth
and coordinate with the licensed clinical personnel completing the psychosocial
assessment. The psychiatrist must review the youth’s medication history, current
needs, and prescriptions. This includes adjustment of medication and dosages, as
necessary. The facility will need to review the most recent completed treatment
plan at the youth’s admission to determine if the treatment plan indicates the
youth needs psychiatric services to be completed within the first 15 calendar days.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Utilizing a date calculator to determine treatment plan due dates.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
3

Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2023 Renewal Inspection: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during
this reporting period as a result of the Renewal Inspection completed
5/22/2023. The violations were noted for employee personnel files,
employee training, and treatment plans. The CAP contained action items
to ensure documents required for employee files were obtained prior to
hire by utilizing a checklist to confirm all required documents were
obtained. The facility implemented a system for human resources to
email prompt sheet reminders to supervisors a month prior to evaluations
being completed, it appears this system did not work as there was no
follow up from human resources on obtaining the evaluations that were
due to be completed. The facility created a prompt sheet reminder for
when treatment plans were due, it appears that the date was calculated
by month and did not consider one of the months had thirty-one days
resulting in a treatment plan being overdue by one day. The facilities
CAP was effective as marked by significant improvement of rule
violations found during this interim inspection.
• SIR2023C0000720SI, CAP approved 10/9/2023 was a result of repeat
violations for Rule 400.142(1) (e) due to the facility not reviewing hospital
discharge paperwork summary resulting in the facility not obtaining
medication and providing the medication to the youth, and Rule 400.4112
(4) (a) due to staff unprofessionalism and the facility not ensuring the
hospital safety plan was implemented into the facilities safety plan. The
facility implemented a formal discharge protocol to be used when youth
are discharged from the hospital and the social service worker and on-
call supervisor are informed of the instructions on the discharge form.
Professionalism training was provided to all staff and has been added to
the new hire training.
• SIR2024SIC0001200, CAP approved 4/3/2024 was a result of repeat
violation for Rule 400.4159 (5) due to three restraints not being
performed per the facilities restraint model technique and Rule 400.4163
(5) as the facility had three restraints that were not documented as
restraints in MiSACWIS. The facility retrained the staff who was involved
with the restraints, discussed restraint to be used with specific youth at
team meetings, and has implemented restraint reviews to be completed
4

by the Handle with Care trainer and/or Chief Administrator to ensure
proper techniques are being used. The facility restrained all staff on
restraint definition per PA 116 and amended the incident reports in
MiSACWIS to accurately reflect the incidents as restraints.
Financial Overview
The facilities financial audit was reviewed by Michigan Department of Health &
Human Services Bureau of Audit due to concerns noted in past audit findings.
Progress was noted, but there were repeated findings for the 2022 audit. Corrective
action will be requested and required to mitigate the finding by the Bureau of Audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
findings in Renewal inspection had a positive impact as the CAP assisted in
ensuring compliance for this interim inspection as human resources now utilizes a
checklist that is reviewed by both human resources and the training coordinator
prior to an employee starting preservice training to ensure all required documents
have been received.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by management at the facility and well trained.
Staff like the refresher training opportunities that are available and feel the facility
meets all training needs. Staff reported feeling safe and youth being well cared for.
Staff did not have any concerns. The facility is short staffed currently as this time of
year is when several staff complete school and return home for the summer. Staff
have been working to fill shifts as well as upper management has been assisting in
shift coverage to avoid staff burn out. The facility has new staff currently completing
new hire training and is looking to start another new hire training in the next few
weeks.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. All youth report their needs
are being met at the facility and no concerns. Youth report feeling safe. Youth did
indicate not liking some of the food options on the menu and staff have worked to
change the menu to have meals the youth prefer.
Description of Agency Walk Through
5

An onsite inspection and walk through of the facility occurred on May 14, 2024.
The facility was clean and there were no safety concerns. All youth bedrooms were
viewed to have appropriate bedding, medications and cleaning supplies were
secured as required. There was sufficient food in the home.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
